intro: Leptecophylla oxycedrus, commonly known as the Mediterranean boxwood, is a species of evergreen shrub native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Buxaceae and is characterized by its dense, compact growth habit and small, oval-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 1–2 meters and is often cultivated as a ornamental plant due to its hardy nature and ability to tolerate pruning. Its leaves are dark green and glossy, providing year-round visual interest in gardens and landscapes. Leptecophylla oxycedrus is well-suited to coastal areas and can thrive in well-drained soils with full sun to partial shade.
